user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of SHA1ProcessMessageBlock:
```c
static void
SHA1ProcessMessageBlock (struct SHA1Context *context)
{
  const uint32_t K[] = { 0x5A827999, 0x6ED9EBA1, 0x8F1BBCDC, 0xCA62C1D6 };
  int i;
  uint32_t temp;
  uint32_t W[80];
  uint32_t A, B, C, D, E;

  for (i = 0; i < 16; i++)
  {
    W[i] = ((uint32_t) context->message_block[i * 4]) << 24;
    W[i] |= ((uint32_t) context->message_block[i * 4 + 1]) << 16;
    W[i] |= ((uint32_t) context->message_block[i * 4 + 2]) << 8;
    W[i] |= context->message_block[i * 4 + 3];
  }
  for (i = 16; i < 80; i++)
  {
    W[i]
      = SHA1CircularShift (1, W[i - 3] ^ W[i - 8] ^ W[i - 14] ^ W[i - 16]);
  }
  A = context->intermediate_hash[0];
  B = context->intermediate_hash[1];
  C = context->intermediate_hash[2];
  D = context->intermediate_hash[3];
  E = context->intermediate_hash[4];
  for (i = 0; i < 20; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + ((B & C) | ((~B) & D)) + E + W[i]
           + K[0];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  for (i = 20; i < 40; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + (B ^ C ^ D) + E + W[i] + K[1];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  for (i = 40; i < 60; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + ((B & C) | (B & D) | (C & D)) + E
           + W[i] + K[2];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  for (i = 60; i < 80; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + (B ^ C ^ D) + E + W[i] + K[3];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  context->intermediate_hash[0] += A;
  context->intermediate_hash[1] += B;
  context->intermediate_hash[2] += C;
  context->intermediate_hash[3] += D;
  context->intermediate_hash[4] += E;
  context->message_block_index = 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Rule 17.8 concerns modifying a function parameter itself (the pointer value), not the object it points to. In this function the parameter is the pointer 'context'. The code only dereferences 'context' to read and to write fields (e.g. context->intermediate_hash[...] += ..., context->message_block_index = 0, context->message_block[...] accesses). Modifying the object pointed to is permitted by the rule; what would be disallowed is any assignment or arithmetic that changes the pointer variable 'context' itself (e.g. context = ..., context++, etc.). There are no statements in the function that assign to or change the pointer variable 'context', so no fragments need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
